Description: City Council amends the Transportation Element of the General Plan, adopting the Mobility Plan 2035 to guide a 20-year multimodal Complete Streets build-out across L.A.
LA adopts Vision Zero, committing to eliminate all traffic deaths by 2025 with data-driven safety measures and enforcement initiatives.
Released as the companion manual to Mobility Plan 2035, it sets new street-design standards prioritizing safety and access for walkers, bikers, transit, and drivers.
City Council adopts resolutions replacing Level of Service with vehicle-miles-traveled (VMT) as the CEQA metric for transportation impacts, in anticipation of SB 743.
LADOT & City Planning publish a draft update to the Transportation Demand Management ordinance, expanding requirements to most multi-family residential developments.
Council receives report on citywide rollout of Complete Streets safety projects on Vision Zero Priority Corridors, with four projects built by 2021.
City Council adopts further Vision Zero measures directing LADOT to accelerate safety countermeasures on high-injury corridors citywide.

Activities Local Law 2019 — new Local Law commenced, replacing earlier versions

Transport Strategy 2030 — long-term transport vision endorsed by Council

Closure of the Voie Georges-Pompidou (pedestrianisation of the river-bank road between the Tuileries and Henri-IV tunnels)
Low Emission Zone intra-muros (restriction of Crit’Air 4, 5 and non-classés vehicles within Paris city limits)

Reserved bus-only lane on Rue de Londres (8ᵉ arr.) (Arrêté n° 2023P110037)

Description: Mayor Sadiq Khan outlines a new £10 daily surcharge on the oldest, highest-polluting petrol and diesel vehicles entering central London, to run alongside the existing £11.50 Congestion Charge.
Implemented 07:00–18:00 on weekdays within the Congestion Charge zone, adding £10 for pre-Euro 4 vehicles (registered before 2006).
Replacing the T-Charge, the world’s first 24-hour ULEZ begins in the same area as the Congestion Charge zone, applying a daily emissions-standard surcharge to non-compliant vehicles.

In response to COVID-19, TfL and the Mayor unveil emergency measures to reallocate road space for walking and cycling—fast-track pop-up cycle lanes, widened pavements, bus gates, and low-traffic neighbourhood schemes.
A world-first lorry-safety scheme requiring all HGVs over 12 tonnes operating in Greater London to hold a free safety permit based on a star-rating of drivers’ direct forward and side vision.
ULEZ grows to cover all Inner London boroughs up to—but not including—the North and South Circular Roads, an 18× increase in area serving 3.8 million residents.
Temporary pandemic-era extensions end: the £15 daily charge is retained, but hours revert to Mon–Fri 07:00–18:00 and Sat–Sun 12:00–18:00, with Christmas–New Year suspension.
The ULEZ boundary expands to all 32 London boroughs (over 1,500 km²), bringing roughly 9 million people into the charge zone and further cutting non-compliant vehicle traffic.

Description: Regula de manera experimental las dársenas de carga/descarga y ascenso/descenso de pasajeros en la Av. Cabildo (de Franklin D. Roosevelt a Pico) por 90 días.
Se lanza la plataforma de participación ciudadana para recoger propuestas sobre semáforos, veredas y mejoras al transporte público.
Modifica el Código de Tránsito y Transporte (Ley 2148) en lo relativo a la habilitación de conductores y la base de cálculo de tarifas preestablecidas para taxis.
Complementa el Código de Tránsito y Transporte estableciendo que las normativas particulares de estacionamiento no previstas en el Anexo I se regirán por el Código porteño.
Sanciona diversas disposiciones sobre movilidad y organización del transporte público en la Ciudad Autónoma de Buenos Aires.
Modifican múltiples artículos del Código de Tránsito (definiciones de vehículos, piloto experimental, cálculo de tarifa de taxis) y aprueban su cronograma de aplicación.
Ajustan procedimientos para disposición de vehículos retenidos, definen nuevos términos (“Sube y Baja”) en el Código y aprueban protocolo de cursos de educación vial.
Amended the NYC Administrative Code to expand pedestrian right-of-way and pedestrian control signal standards.
Required DOT to implement leading pedestrian intervals and exclusive pedestrian phases at high-crash intersections.
New York State approved congestion pricing for Manhattan below 60th Street, the first U.S. city to do so.
Mayor de Blasio announced the conversion of 40 miles of city streets to pedestrian-only zones during the COVID-19 pandemic.
Permitted restaurants to use sidewalks and curb lanes for outdoor dining to support social distancing and economic recovery.
NYC speed cameras authorized to operate 24 hours/day, 7 days/week to enhance automated speed enforcement.
NYC DOT published a final rule to make the Open Streets program permanent across designated city streets.
State government policy aiming to reduce road accidents by 25% and fatalities by 30% by 2020 through coordinated measures
